title: Blue Link worthless
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 8, 2020
content: My boyfriend and I just bought 2 brand new Hyundai's.  Both 2020 models.  Obviously both are equipped with Blue Link.  Blue Link has not worked on either vehicle from the day we got them.  Neither of us are able to use any of the functions.  The remote start would be especially useful as we live in Colorado and both work nights.  We have been in contact with Hyundai customer service who referred us to Blue Link customer service.  We both had "tickets" started for them to look into this problem.  Blue Link and their engineers insist that we do not have adequate service to use these functions.  This is after we have provided ample documentation to prove that we do have more than enough service to use these functions.  We are extremely dissatisfied with Hyundai and Blue Link for their lack of wanting to make this issue right.  We took our vehicles to our local Hyundai service center and they said that they have had to replace many radios due to this issue.  Apparently the radio is where the "brain" of  Blue Link is.  But for some reason Blue Link is refusing to do this for us.  The Blue Link feature is one of the features we were looking forward to having on our vehicles.  Utterly disappointed.  We will probably have to have remote starts installed on our vehicles out of our own pockets because Hyundai Blue Link engineers apparently don't care.

title: COMPLETELY UNRELIABLE 'FEATURE'
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 13, 2019
content: This lovely but mostly USELESS feature was included for 3 years on my Hyundai Kona 2019.  When it comes time to renew and actually pay for it, I would prefer being REIMBURSED for the supposed EXTRA, "free" 3 years of this GIFTY-TYPE feature that helped sell me this car.  Oooooh!  Look what we're giving you for FREE!!!!  I'd like to be reimbursed for being deceived, disappointed and disillusioned. For every time I send a command that works, such as lock the doors from inside the house because I forgot, I get an AVERAGE of 5-10 error messages telling me that "this service is not available at this time; try again later."  How MUCH later?  I've tried for an HOUR to start my car because it's cold out there and I'm old in here.  Why is it unavailable MOST OF THE TIME?  There is absolutely NO WAY I would ever 'renew' this feature and throw money away on it.  It's all but useless.  Blue Link and Hyundai need to put their heads together and figure out how to fix this extremely disappointing "feature".  It stinks.  If I depended on this feature to actually work, I'd be late for church, doctor appointments. picking up my grandson from school, etc., etc., etc.  It is 99% undependable.  What you get free is a HEADACHE.

title: DIDNT WORK BUT DOES NOW! Yay! 2016 SONATA
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 28, 2017
content: I had the same trouble as everyon else. I kept getting the "disable/enable message too" so I sent Amazon an email. They replied to call it in. I did and I'm glad bc the issue was simple. I have a bluelink subscription, I set everything up in the Alexa app and it didn't work. I am also apart of a amazon household account and my husband is the primary member. So his profile is on Alexa first. All I had to do was tell Alexa "switch profiles" or you can say your name+profile. Once on my profile I say "Alexza tell bluelink to start my sonata" she asks for my PIN I tell her and she sends the request. VERY EASY! However if you're not under the right profile she'll do nothing because the skill needs to be enabled on the other members app/phone. Hope this helps!

title: Works brilliantly - *if* and only *if* your Hyundai has the right hardware
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 21, 2016
content: Good Lord people.  Starting with the 2015 Sonata/Genesis Hyundai introduced AVN 4.0/4.5 (do a search) which includes additional h/w supported functionality over their earlier nav/media systems.  It's that functionality that allows newer cars to be used with Alexa.  There will never be an update for older cars as the changes are h/w not s/w.  So either buy a newer Hyundai or don't buy an Echo if its primary purpose would be to control your car. I traded a 2014 Elantra GT for a 2016 specifically for the updated Nav capabilities which also include Android Auto and Apple Car Play.  For the record owners of older Hyundais won't be getting those features either for the same reason they can't use Alexa.  It's the h/w.

title: Expected way more-very disappointed
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 17, 2021
content: I purchased a 2020 Hyundai Santa Fe a month and a half ago which came enabled with Bluelink. I was very excited about this service for a few reasons 1. I live in Montana and our average temperature this last week was around -25 F, the idea that I was going to be able to remote start my vehicle was a very attractive feature. 2. The idea that I would also be able to diagnose issues with my vehicle was also a very enticing feature. The unfortunate part is that those ideas have remained just that...ideas. Hyundai BlueLink has failed to follow through with my requests for assistance on getting my BlueLink activated. I initially submitted a ticket on 1/8/21 and they have yet find a resolution as to why my BlueLink is not activating. On top of not being able to find a resolution yet, their communication with me regarding my ticket has been virtually non-existent. The initial rep I spoke with, the one I filed a ticket with, stated they would either have a resolution of follow up with me in 3-5 business days...7 days later with no response, I had to contact BlueLink to get an update. They gave me a vague answer stating "yep, engineers are still working on it, we will follow up in 3-5 business days". Again, 7 days later with no response, I contacted BlueLink for an update; I got the same answer as before. Again I waited 7 business days to follow up where I then requested to speak with a supervisor. The supervisor was helpful (although he couldn't give me any more of answer as to what was going on behind the scenes) he did make it a point to call me back the following Friday. Unfortunately, this supervisor told me that day was going to be his last day (surprise, surprise, I'd be looking for another job too since communication was probably an issue for him too). After that conversation I heard nothing more from Hyundai BlueLink. Fast forward to this last weekend...My husband and I left for a road trip and guess what? My new car broke down on us! And, you guessed it...because my BlueLink issue had yet to be resolved we were unable to diagnose what the check engine light was for AND road side assistance had issues locating us.Fast forward again, we get my car to a Hyundai dealership. They are unable to read the check engine light because their Hyundai software isn't working! 2 rental cars, 1 night in a hotel and 3 days later....I get a call from Jobe at Hyundai BlueLink. He asks if I can access the head mount to try something. I let him know that no...I can't, because my vehicle is 200 miles away at the dealership getting worked on. He then asks if he can call me back in a week for me to try whatever it was he was wanting with the head mount....I asked if he could simply contact the dealership where my car is at so that they (being the so called Hyundai/BlueLink professionals) could troubleshoot and get it fixed...thinking that would be the easiest, most logical approach to getting this issue resolved. I guess I thought wrong, Jobe continued on (talking over me and getting obviously flustered) stated that was not something they could do because the engineers don't communicate with the dealerships or something like that, to be honest his response did not make sense. It is very likely that I just do not understand how there business operations work, however, with their history of poor communication, I also find it likely that Jobe just didn't know how to respond to my question. Jobe ultimately said that he would contact the dealership where my car is at...who knows what will happen at that point...that is if he or anybody at BlueLink follows up for that matter.I will be posting this review on every platform I can in hopes that the right people at Hyundai/BlueLink find this message, they should know what a disappointment it has been to work with their company.

title: Rename and rewrite the whole thing!
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 8, 2018
content: This skill is an absolute mess. It has NEVER worked to execute a single command to my 2018 Leaf. Even accounting for the annoying authentication process, and the horribly slow XM data speeds, and the clunky voice commands I can't even begin to imagine someone was paid to write this. I absolutely LOVE my new Leaf but this app needs serious work. Here, I'll rewrite your patch notes to reflect better syntax.----------This skill has been renamed to "My LEAF" to better serve human methods of speaking.The My LEAF* Alexa skill allows MY11-17 Nissan LEAF owners to access these features:‚Ä¢ Check battery status‚ÄúAlexa, ask My LEAF what is the battery status‚Äù‚Ä¢ Remotely start charging‚ÄúAlexa, tell My LEAF to start charging‚Äù‚Ä¢ Remotely set schedule to turn on climate control‚ÄúAlexa, tell My LEAF to turn on the Climate Control on Monday at 7:00 AM‚Äù‚Ä¢ Remotely get your LEAF ready to leave by turning on climate control and starting battery charge‚ÄúAlexa, tell My LEAF to get ready to leave‚ÄùThe NissanConnect EV Alexa skill allows MY18 Nissan LEAF owners to access these features:‚Ä¢ All of the features listed above for MY11-17 vehicles, plus:‚Ä¢ Set cabin temperature‚ÄúAlexa, tell My LEAF to set the temperature to 75 degrees‚Äù‚Ä¢ Check cabin temperature‚ÄúAlexa, ask My LEAF what is the cabin temperature‚Äù‚Ä¢ Remotely lock or unlock vehicle doors‚ÄúAlexa, tell My LEAF to unlock the doors‚Äù‚Ä¢ Remotely turn on and off the horn‚ÄúAlexa, tell My LEAF to honk the horn‚Äù‚Ä¢ Turn the lights on and off‚ÄúAlexa, tell My LEAF to turn on the lights‚Äù----------

title: Clunky, slow, and failing
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 19, 2018
content: As of today, when I finally get Alexa to recognize my request (which fails 80% of the time for me; saying "NissanConnect EV" is cumbersome at best), it immediately fails the request.  "I'm now processing your get battery status request.  I'm unable to get your battery status at the moment, please try again later."When/if the basics start working again, it would be /far/ more useful if every round-trip request for status or commands to the car completed in less than 30 or 40 seconds, which feels like an eternity compared to every other skill on the market.I'd really like this skill to be useful, and I hope it (and the NissanConnect EV backend) can be improved in the future.

title: It Really Works even on an Antique 2011 Leaf
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 19, 2018
content: Being the original owner of a 2011 Leaf, I have become dubious of anything that Nissan claims is "new!" Today I was offered Alexa integration... and after a stumbling start, I was impressed. Stumbling only because I needed to link my "My Nissan" account to Alexa and I have about four versions of these accounts as I tried and failed to get Carwings to work in a satisfactory fashion. Anyway, with the right account (now titled Nissan Connect) tied to Alexa, I gave her the first example presented on my skill screen which was "Alexa ask Nissan Connect EV to check the battery status on my Leaf."  She immediately dismissed my command as nonsense (soft ding) but no comment.  I tried again but slower as you would speak to someone not familiar with English. This time I got a more formal rejection "I don't know how to do that." Okay... I switch from my living room Echo to my office Echo Show and tried one more time. I got silence as the blue "working on it" bar cycled and then (soft ding) nothing.  Blast it! Okay, one more time... carefully enunciating every syllable... "Alexa, ask Nissan Connect EV to check the battery status on my Leaf" And after a moment, with blue bar cycling, Alexa said "One moment while I process your request" and a moment later she reported a lot more than I asked for including the charging voltage and the expected finish time and even offered to send a notice to my preferred Email or SMS address when charging was complete.  It worked. I found that if I mixed the words to check my Leaf battery status, Alexa didn't do it... but if I stuck to the quoted sentence above, it worked every time.  Great. On the down side, I wish that the skill command were a bit more simple than what is required (perhaps "Ask Nissan Connect to check my Leaf battery) and perhaps the result might be more accurate: Alexa reported that my battery was 133% charged and would be fully charged in 30 minutes.  133%?  Wow. Heck with buying a new 2018 Leaf when my old 2011 can be rejuvenated so easily via Alexa.  I love this addition and will use it frequently!

If you get to the skill, it might work once, but come back in an hour and you get told you need to link the skill to your account, again and again and again ...Rewrite it, change the name.

title: Have 2018 Leaf with Premium Connect services. The app ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 27, 2018
content: Have 2018 Leaf with Premium Connect services.  The app does work, but sporadically; Also, as others have stated, the command line is very long and awkward.  In addition, the various command lines do not follow the same pattern making its use from memory very difficult.  And some requests/commands are audibly answered while others just give a audible ding that request was processed.  In each case, I used the suggested wording to issue these commands.Example #1, using my Echo Show, I asked for battery status and only got an audible cue that it was processed (Response option set to Brief Mode); however, nothing heard about status or displayed on Echo Show.  When I opened Alexa app on phone, my question and response was displayed in the app.  I subsequently asked the same command and Alexa reported "OK, it would do that, and then reported unable to do so at this time"Example #2, using Echo Show, I asked to sound the horn.  After a few seconds, the horn started blowing.Example, using Echo Show, I asked for doors to be locked.  Alexa responded and asked for my PIN.  Alexa reported it would send the command.If the app skill wording is shortened and made to follow same format, it would be much improved.

title: Works when it works, which is only if car is awakened first.
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 23, 2018
content: Easy parts: added skill to Alexa, linked account, all checked out.Hard part: don‚Äôt expect it to work quickly.  The command first has to awaken the car (Model 3) and get whatever info was asked for.  If car is awake, the response is very quick.  If not, Alexa will give a message about being unable to connect and that the car is either asleep or disconnected.  One workaround would be to preclude the car from going to sleep fully, but I think that‚Äôs a non-starter for me.  A solution might be to extend the time between when Alexa sends a signal to awaken the car and when Alexa asks for desired information sufficient to give the car time to awaken.

title: Great but needs slightly longer timeout
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 28, 2018
content: I‚Äôm having a great time turning on the heater in ‚Äòmy car‚Äô in the mornings.The one problem is that the timeout that the skill waits for the car to respond is just slightly too short for the car wake up time. The first request always fails with a message‚Äô, ‚Äòerror, cannot communicate with vehicle. Car could (not have service) or is not awake‚Äô.If you immediately try again, it works almost instantly.Can you extend the timeout so the first request ends up getting a response and working?Thanks!

title: Latest Tesla update Feb 21 break the login and token.
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 8, 2021
content: Tesla has changed how they do authentication (referred to now as v3). Every app and site that uses the API has to be updated. Here is a work around to get a new token. On IOS download AuthAppForTesla, login with your Tesla credential to generate a new token. Now wait for around 10mins for Tesla Server to Authenticate. Now inside Alexa link with new token you generated.

title: updated: try saying ‚Äústart engine‚Äù - skill does not work and no help if you call them
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 9, 2021
content: I am updating my review to two stars because I believe I found the solution to the start command not working. At least this is working for the time being. Try saying ‚Äúopen NissanConnect Services‚Äù, then say ‚Äústart the engine‚Äù. This has been working the last couple of days for me. I am still keeping it at two stars because I don‚Äôt know for how long this will work, and after several phone calls and even a callback from Amazon, no one could help me. I discovered this solution on my own, so hopefully it will work for someone else too.  I can‚Äôt believe no one knows the commands and they keep changing them.  She still does not recommend my vehicle name, Kicks, so I still cant say it.original review:Alexa says ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry I‚Äôm having trouble try it in a little while.‚Äù She also does not recognize the vehicle name kicks.  she wants to play Kicks 105 radio station instead of starting my car!  When I called Nissan connect services, all she could do is tell me to disable and re-enable the skill. Obviously that does not work!

title: Useless

Thus the system keeps disconnecting. This is my 2nd brand new Nissan and its doing the same as my old one.

title: Not useful at all
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 22, 2020
content: this app is pretty useless as its integration is horrible.too many steps and voice commands to do something simple.me. ‚ÄúAlexa, tell NissanConnect Services to start my car‚Äùnote, you cant just say ‚Äúcar‚Äù, you have to specify the modelAlexa. ‚ÄúYou have NissanConnect Setvices enabled. Would you like to open it‚Äùwhy should it have to be ‚Äòopened‚Äô first?me. ‚Äúyes‚ÄùAlexa then blabs on about my taste in automobiles and asks for the PIN. Asking for pin is fine, dont need the extra commentary.Alexa. ‚ÄúThe start command has been sent. Is there anything else I can do for you today?‚Äùme. ‚ÄúNo‚ÄùAlexa. ‚Äúsorry I didnt understand that. if you would like help...‚Äù blah blah blahsee, actually it cant do anything else. the ‚Äúdo for tou@ and ‚Äúhelp‚Äù is limited specifically to the skill itself.you cant ask Alexa anything else. Hell, you can even tell Alexa to stop or exit.me. ‚ÄúAlexa, exit‚ÄùAlexa. ‚Äúsorry I didnt understand that. if you would like help...‚Äù blah blah blahwhat should happen:1. Ask alexa to ‚Äúhave NCS start my car‚Äù2. Alexa says Ok, asks for pin. nothing more.3. give pin4. Alexa says OK and that the command was sent.done.(update 12/2021-over last year it hasnt been any better. still have to open the skill first, and still have to specify the model. now if you had 2 Nissans I could see why, but when you only have 1 car why ‚Äústart my car‚Äù doesnt work is baffling.

title: doesnt work!  ...updated: it's better now!

I do think Nissan should offer their Connect Services as a standard feature included on all their cars (at least the basic connect services .. lock, crank, horn, lights, 911, find if stolen, etc.) -- NOT as a paid subscription service.  I would not pay a monthly subscription for this, so super glad it was included with my murano.
